channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: Is the EU planning a social media ban for children in 2026?
Could Pakistan’s Imran Khan lose vision because of eye condition?
The Learjet 45, the plane that crashed with Ajit Pawar on board in Baramati
Why Ajit Pawar was fondly called the ‘dada of Maharashtra politics’
Amid Nipah cases in India, which countries are screening for the deadly virus?
How Trump is pushing the world closer to India, China
Gaza Peace Board: Why India must reject Trump’s offer
item.description: India should not contribute to the further erosion of multilateral norms. Historically, it has maintained a balanced position on the Palestine–Israel question, grounded in its belief in the viability of a two-state solution; it must now adhere to this position firmly and consistently

item.title: Xi’s China: When too much control becomes a systemic risk
item.description: China’s future depends on whether Xi Jinping's centralised model can reintroduce internal correction mechanisms, tolerate limited decentralisation, and restore administrative flexibility before demographic and economic pressures peak

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s nuclear deterrence: Trump can attack Iran, not North Korea
item.description: In a war with the US, North Korea stands to lose everything. The military asymmetry between the two nations would make the situation more volatile with Kim Jong-un likely to make a pre-emptive nuclear strike

item.title: 77th Republic Day: How India is biding its time, carving a geo-strategic space in an uncertain world
item.description: India is moving from adaptation to actively trying to influence the global agenda, using its unique position as a growing economic power and democratic voice for a multipolar, inclusive world order

item.title: How Xi Jinping’s power grab spells global looming crisis
item.description: As Xi Jinping amasses unprecedented power through relentless purges, China risks internal chaos and global instability in an era of one-man rule.

item.title: The Oscars don’t reward cinema, they ratify the narrative of the moment
item.description: Awards function less as arbiters of cinema than as archivists of institutional mood. They tell us what the industry wished to reward in a particular year—what anxieties it sought to soothe, what narratives it needed to elevate, and what discomforts it chose to avoid
